content.text: Bash head Command - Display the beginning of a file
Using the head Command
The head command is used to display the first part of files.
content.html: The head command is used to display the first part of files.

content.text: It's particularly useful for previewing the start of a file to understand its structure.
content.html: It's particularly useful for previewing the start of a file to understand its structure.

content.text: All examples below use the logfile.txt file:

content.code:
line 01
line 02
line 03
line 04
line 05
line 06
line 07
line 08
line 09
line
10


..
.
content.code_html:
line 01
line 02
line 03
line 04
line 05
line 06
line 07
line 08
line 09
line 10
...

content.text: Basic Usage
The head command displays the first 10 lines of a file by default:
content.html: The head command displays the first 10 lines of a file by default:

content.code:
head
logfile.txt
line 01
line 02
line 03
line 04
line 05
line 06
line 07
line 08
line 09
line 10
content.code_html:
head logfile.txt
line 01
line 02
line 03
line 04
line 05
line 06
line 07
line 08
line 09
line 10

content.text: Options
The head command has several options used to customize its behavior:
content.html: The head command has several options used to customize its behavior:

content.text: Option: -n [number]
The -n option allows you to specify the number of lines to display from the start of the file. By default, head shows the first 10 lines.
content.html: The -n option allows you to specify the number of lines to display from the start of the file. By default, head shows the first 10 lines.

content.code:
head
-n
5
logfile.txt
line 01
line 02
line 03
line 04
line 05
content.code_html:
head -n 5 logfile.txt
line 01
line 02
line 03
line 04
line 05

content.text: Option: -c [number]
The -c option allows you to display the first [number] bytes of a file instead of lines.
content.html: The -c option allows you to display the first [number] bytes of a file instead of lines.

content.code_html:
head -c 20 logfile.txt
line 01
line 02
line

content.text: Option: Multiple Files
The head command can be used to display the beginning of multiple files. By default, it prints the file name as a header before the content of each file.
content.html: The head command can be used to display the beginning of multiple files. By default, it prints the file name as a header before the content of each file.

content.code:
ead -n
3
logfile.txt logfile2.txt
==> logfile.txt <==
line 01
line 02
line 03

==> logfile2.txt <==
line 01
line 02
line 03
content.code_html:
ead -n 3 logfile.txt logfile2.txt
==> logfile.txt <==
line 01
line 02
line 03

==> logfile2.txt <==
line 01
line 02
line 03

content.text: Option: -q
The -q option suppresses the printing of headers when multiple files are being processed. This is useful when you want to view the contents of multiple files without the file names being printed.
content.html: The -q option suppresses the printing of headers when multiple files are being processed. This is useful when you want to view the contents of multiple files without the file names being printed.

content.code:
head
-q -n
3
logfile.txt logfile2.txt
line 01
line 02
line 03
line 01
line 02
line 03
content.code_html:
head -q -n 3 logfile.txt logfile2.txt
line 01
line 02
line 03
line 01
line 02
line 03
